H0.text: A fault is the feature that results when plates of different densities converge and one plate slips under the other.

H1.text: A ridge is the feature that results when plates of different densities converge and one plate slips under the other.

H2.text: A trench is the feature that results when plates of different densities converge and one plate slips under the other.

H3.text: A rift zone is the feature that results when plates of different densities converge and one plate slips under the other.

A4.text: The point where the slab begins to plunge downwards is marked by an oceanic trench.

A5.text: The subducting plate may have enough traction on the bottom of the continental plate to cause the upper plate to contract by folding, faulting, crustal thickening, and mountain building.

A6.text: Trenches, along with volcanic arcs and Wadatiâ€“Benioff zones (zones of earthquakes under a volcanic arc) are diagnostic of convergent plate boundaries and their deeper manifestations, subduction zones.

A7.text: The formation of these bending faults is suppressed where oceanic ridges or large seamounts are subducting into the trench.
